'''Lou Pride''' (May 24, 1944 - June 5, 2012)<ref name="Obit">{{cite web|url=http://legacy.suburbanchicagonews.com/obituaries/stng-newssun/obituary.aspx?pid=157993821#fbLoggedOut |title=Lou Pride Obituary: View Lou Pride's Obituary by News Sun |publisher=Legacy.suburbanchicagonews.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-08}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] blues and soul singer and songwriter.<ref name="AMG"/> Some sources state his year of birth was 1950.<ref name="Dead"/>  He is best known for his compositions "Long Arm Of The Blues" and "Love From A Stone".<ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://www.thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2012.html |title=2012 January To June |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2013-08-08}}</ref> Pride had a cult following amongst [[British people|British]] [[Northern soul]] aficionados.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Andrew
| last= Wilson
| year= 2007
| title= Northern Soul
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Willan Publishing 
| location= [[Cullompton]], [[Devon]], [[England]] 
| isbn= 9781-84392-208-7
| page= 37}}</ref>

Before his death, [[Allmusic]] noted that Pride had a "smooth, uptown southern voice,"<ref name="Twisting">{{cite web|author=Andrew Hamilton |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/twisting-the-knife-mw0000033018 |title=Twisting the Knife - Lou Pride | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=1997-10-21 |accessdate=2013-08-08}}</ref> and was "more known for performances in blues clubs and festivals than his artistry in the studio."<ref name="I Won't">{{cite web|author=Andrew Hamilton |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/i-wont-give-up-mw0000958520 |title=I Won't Give Up - Lou Pride | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2000-06-27 |accessdate=2013-08-08}}</ref>

==Biography==
He was born '''George Louis Pride''',<ref name="Dead"/> in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States.<ref name="AMG"/> Pride grew up on Chicago's north side and attended the First Baptist Church, where the pastor was [[Nat King Cole]]'s father.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Obit"/>

After [[conscription]] in the [[United States Army]],<ref name="Obit"/> Pride met and married a female singer and they settled in [[El Paso, Texas]].<ref name="AMG"/>  They performed as a singing duo before, after seeing [[B.B. King]] perform live, Pride concentrated his singing future around the blues and soul music genres.<ref name="SunTimes"/> Pride recorded his first two [[Single (music)|singles]] in the early 1970s. These were "I'm Com'un Home In The Morn'un" (1972) and "Your Love Is Fading," the latter released by Suemi Records.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Oldies">{{cite web|url=http://www.oldies.com/artist-biography/Lou-Pride.html |title=Lou Pride Biography |publisher=OLDIES.com |date=1950-05-24 |accessdate=2013-08-08}}</ref> After relocating to [[New Mexico]], he recorded sporadically whilst constantly performing in blues [[nightclub|clubs]] and at [[Music festival|festivals]] on the [[chitlin' circuit]].<ref name="Soul Blues">{{cite web|url=http://blues.about.com/b/2012/06/07/soul-blues-singer-lou-pride-r-i-p.htm |title=Soul-Blues Singer Lou Pride, R.I.P |publisher=Blues.about.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-08}}</ref> Other tracks of his that were released over this period included  "Look Out on Love," "We're Only Fooling Ourselves," "You've Got to Work for Love," and "Been Such a Long Time."<ref name="AMG"/>

Pride's debut album was entitled, ''Very Special'' (1979), which was released by Black Gold Entertainment. Several singles were issued before ''Gone Bad for a Very Special Reason'' (1988) was released, which had an almost an identical playlist to his debut effort.<ref name="AMG"/>

After returning to Chicago, he became acquainted with [[Curtis Mayfield]], which saw ''Gone Bad Again'' (1990) being issued.<ref name="Obit"/> However, Pride's recordings remained second place to performing live. The WMB Records release, ''Love at Last'' (1995), contained re-recordings of several of Pride's earlier cuts. His 1997 [[Ichiban Records|Ichiban]] release was ''Twisting the Knife'', followed by ''I Won't Give Up''  (2000).<ref name="AMG"/> Pride signed a [[recording contract]] with [[Severn Records]] in 2002, which preceded his first release for them, ''Words of Caution.''<ref name="Soul Blues"/> His early 1970s recordings were collected on the [[compilation album]], ''The Memphis/El Paso Sessions 1970-1973'', which Severn issued in June 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.last.fm/music/Lou+Pride/+wiki |title=Lou Pride’s Biography – Free listening, concerts, stats, & pictures at |publisher=Last.fm |date=2013-01-15 |accessdate=2013-08-08}}</ref> Allmusic noted that the collection "remains a treasure trove of previously obscure soul music that spotlights one of the many great singers almost lost to history."<ref>{{cite web|author=Hal Horowitz |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-memphis-el-paso-sessions-1970-73-mw0000034218 |title=The Memphis/El Paso Sessions 1970-73 - Lou Pride | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2003-06-24 |accessdate=2013-08-08}}</ref>

In 2004, Pride undertook a brief tour in the [[United Kingdom|UK]]. Alongside [[Darrell Nulisch]], Pride was also the headline act at the Severn Records Soul and Blues Revue, in Chicago, in 2006.<ref name="Oldies"/> Snippets of his composition, "Bringin' Me Back Home," were used in the 2007 [[film]], ''[[Feast of Love]]''.<ref name="SunTimes">{{cite web|url=http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/music/13039764-421/chicago-singer-was-naturally-soul-blues.html |title=Chicago singer Lou Pride ‘was naturally soul blues’ - Chicago Sun-Times |publisher=Suntimes.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-08}}</ref> Pride's appearance at the Severn Soul Review in 2010 was a significant comeback.  He had been booked to appear in 2004, but he had had a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] before he could perform.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soul-source.co.uk/soulforum/topic/3440-lou-pride/ |title=Lou Pride - All About the SOUL - Soul Source Rare and Northern Soul |publisher=Soul-source.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-08-08}}</ref>
 
Following a period of ill health, Pride died in Chicago in June 2012 of natural causes. He was aged 68.<ref name="Obit"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soultracks.com/lou-pride-dies |title=Chicago blues man Lou Pride dies at 68 | SoulTracks - Soul Music Biographies, News and Reviews |publisher=SoulTracks |date= |accessdate=2013-08-08}}</ref>
